author: t2_qq0xl5fs
text:
This just occurred to me last night as I was trying to get to sleep - and kept me awake for ages wondering....

How does the kotlin compiler unambiguously parse an expression which contains generic arguments - how can it tell when a '<' is a delimiter for a generic arguments and when is is a less than?

Think of

    somefunc( andrew<bill, charlie>(david) )

and

    somefunc( mapOf<Cat,Dog>(somePair) )

Both have the same form at the parsing stage before any type information is available.

      somefunc( identifier<identifier,identifier>(identifier) ).

How does the compiler resolve this ambiguity?

&#x200B;

&#x200B;

EDIT:

&#x200B;

I just tried doing some experiments - and the compiler does actually get confused!! Although its a pretty contrived example that I don't think would come up too often in the real world. :-)

It looks like what is happening is the compiler first attempts to interpret '<' as a generic and if it can reach a '>' without hitting a syntax error then accepts that parse, otherwise backtracks and tries interpreting the '<' as a less than.

So this gives some circumstances where a less than is syntactically correct but a greater than isn't (and vice versa)!

    private fun testFunc(a:Boolean, b:Boolean) : Boolean {
         return a && b 
    }
    
    private fun example() {
          val a = 2
          val b = 4
          val c = 6
          val d = 8
          val e = testFunc( a<b, c>d)     // gives a syntax error!!!
          val f = testFunc( a<b, c<d)     // compiles OK
          val g = testFunc( a<b, 6<d)     // compiles OK
          val h = testFunc( (a<b), c>d)   // compiles OK    
    }

<p>Both have the same form at the parsing stage before any type information is available.</p>
<p>How does the compiler resolve this ambiguity?</p>

<p>I just tried doing some experiments - and the compiler does actually get confused!! Although its a pretty contrived example that I don&#39;t think would come up too often in the real world. :-)</p>
<p>It looks like what is happening is the compiler first attempts to interpret &#39;&lt;&#39; as a generic and if it can reach a &#39;&gt;&#39; without hitting a syntax error then accepts that parse
created: otherwise backtracks and tries interpreting the &#39;&lt;&#39; as a less than.</p>

author: <p>So this gives some circumstances where a less than is syntactically correct but a greater than isn&#39;t (and vice versa)!</p>
</div><!-- SC_ON -->"

author: t2_h9q5l1d1
text:
For those devs that have had experience using both Flutter and Kotlin to make mobile apps

I currently have been interning with a company using Flutter and have been offered a part time job in the new year (here in Germany), in the summer though I'll be heading back to the US. I had wanted to apply for internships in the where they use native Android since I'd like to learn a native language as well.

My question is would this be possible with no Kotlin experience, even though I have mobile app experience, is there a large learning curve when trying to transition? and would it be realistic that I would get an internship with only knowing Flutter/Dart and just learn Kotlin as I go, since I have some background with developing mobile apps?

author: t2_bcpqrkki
text:
Running `nm -m shared | grep UIWebView` on a freshly compiled iOS Framework from a freshly made KMM project generates the follow output:

    000000000007e760 (__DATA,__objc_const) non-external __OBJC_$_PROTOCOL_INSTANCE_METHODS_OPT_UIWebViewDelegate
    000000000007e7c8 (__DATA,__objc_const) non-external __OBJC_$_PROTOCOL_METHOD_TYPES_UIWebViewDelegate
    000000000007e748 (__DATA,__objc_const) non-external __OBJC_$_PROTOCOL_REFS_UIWebViewDelegate
    0000000000071f78 (__DATA,__objc_protolist) non-external (was a private external) __OBJC_LABEL_PROTOCOL_$_UIWebViewDelegate
    0000000000084668 (__DATA,__data) non-external (was a private external) __OBJC_PROTOCOL_$_UIWebViewDelegate
    000000000007f8e0 (__DATA,__objc_protorefs) non-external (was a private external) __OBJC_PROTOCOL_REFERENCE_$_UIWebViewDelegate

I've been looking around the internet for specific answers, but I can't find any reference at all. I've asked slack, and everyone doesn't seem to know either. 

I did see that the framework is safe from the **ITMS-90809** rejection, but I still need a specific reason why the UIWebViewDelegate is being included in the binaries. I can't just make random speculations, as my own theory is that UIKit is being included (along with UIWebView references) in the generated Framework, but I'm not sure if that's 100% true. 

I hope anyone can give me specific reason. Thank you very much.
